title: [News] MediaTek Reportedly Teams up with NVIDIA, Aiming AI PC Chip Launch in 1H25
sum:
MediaTek and NVIDIA are reportedly collaborating to develop an AI PC chip, slated for launch in the first half of 2025.  

The chip, currently in the design phase, is expected to be manufactured using TSMC's 3nm node and will be based on ARM architecture. It aims to compete with Qualcomm's Snapdragon X Elite series. Given MediaTek's expertise in power-efficient mobile chips like the Dimensity 9400, the company may leverage its strengths to develop a high-performance and energy-efficient AI PC chip.  

NVIDIA's involvement suggests potential breakthroughs in integrated graphics capabilities. The collaboration also signifies both companies' commitment to expanding into the AI computing market beyond their traditional domains. This partnership is seen as potentially driving innovation in the AI NB (AI Notebook) market, with TrendForce projecting a 20% penetration rate of AI NBs by 2025.  


This development comes after MediaTek announced plans to launch its Dimensity 9400 flagship series in October, designed to support major large language models. This dual focus on both mobile and PC AI demonstrates MediaTek's ambition to become a key player in the rapidly evolving AI landscape.

title: At least 10 killed in Khan Younis as Gaza death toll nears 40,000
sum:
At least 10 people were killed and several wounded in an Israeli airstrike on a home in the Abasan al-Kabira area of eastern Khan Younis. This occurred during an ongoing conflict, with tens of thousands fleeing Israeli military attacks on southern Gaza City.  

Israel’s military is currently investigating a statement from Hamas's armed wing claiming responsibility for the death of an Israeli captive in Gaza and the wounding of two others in a separate incident.

title: Jobhunters flood recruiters with AI-generated CVs
sum:
Jobhunters are increasingly using AI-generated CVs to apply for positions, presenting both opportunities and challenges for recruiters. While these AI-powered resumes can be quickly produced and tailored to specific job descriptions, concerns exist regarding their authenticity and the potential for biases embedded in the algorithms. This trend highlights the evolving landscape of recruitment, where technology plays an increasingly prominent role. 


Some recruiters express concerns about the lack of personalization and genuine human touch in AI-generated CVs, while others acknowledge the efficiency and time-saving benefits they offer.  
The article suggests that this development necessitates a reassessment of traditional hiring practices and raises questions about the future of job applications in the age of artificial intelligence.

title: Growing demand on the dark web for AI abuse images
sum:
A new study from Anglia Ruskin University reveals a growing demand on the dark web for AI-generated child sexual abuse material (CSAM). Researchers analyzed online forums and discovered that individuals are actively seeking information and guidance on creating AI-generated CSAM. 

The study highlights that forum members are sharing tutorials, videos, and advice on using AI to produce this harmful content. Some participants even refer to those creating AI imagery as "artists."  While some express hope for future technological advancements to simplify the process, many are already using existing images of children to manipulate and generate CSAM. 

The researchers emphasize that the misconception surrounding AI-generated images as "victimless" is dangerous. They stress that these images still exploit real children and contribute to the normalization of child abuse.  The study calls for further investigation into the methods used to create AI-CSAM, its distribution patterns, and the impact it has on offenders' behavior.

title: Research into more efficient AI hardware and software supported by AMD donation
sum:
Imperial College London has received a donation from AMD to support research into more efficient AI hardware and software. The donation recognizes the work of Professor George Constantinides and Dr Aaron Zhao in the Department of Electrical and Electronic Engineering.  The funding will be used to improve the performance and energy consumption of large language models (LLMs), similar to ChatGPT.

The research focuses on reconfigurable processors known as field-programmable gate arrays (FPGAs). FPGAs allow programmers to reconfigure sets of logic gates, enabling them to experiment with new processor designs before manufacturing fixed-function integrated circuits. The researchers aim to explore how to configure FPGAs for high-performing LLMs.

A key aspect of the research is finding the optimal design of arithmetic units in processors, which carry out computations over numbers represented using bits.  The team has discovered that machine learning models can tolerate a lower level of precision in number representation, making it possible to optimize for speed and energy efficiency. The research also involves optimizing the design of machine learning models themselves to work effectively on these reconfigurable processors. 


This research could lead to the development of more efficient AI hardware for applications like laptops, cloud assistants, and embedded systems in cars and robots. It could also inform the design of future application-specific processors designed specifically for machine learning.

title: Tokyo deploys AI to detect fires, collapses for rapid quake response
sum:
The Tokyo metropolitan government has implemented an AI-powered system utilizing high-altitude cameras to swiftly detect fires and building collapses during earthquakes. This initiative aims to accelerate disaster response in anticipation of a potential megaquake along the Nankai Trough, which experts warn poses a significant risk to Japan. 

The AI analyzes footage from strategically positioned cameras, identifying smoke or structural damage and transmitting this information to relevant agencies such as police, fire departments, and the Japan Self-Defense Forces. This system enhances response time compared to manual camera operation previously employed.

Currently operational since March, the system encompasses cameras at the Tokyo metropolitan government building, a bridge near Tokyo Bay, and a western location. By the end of fiscal year 2025, two additional cameras will be installed at Tokyo Skytree, expanding coverage to nearly all of Tokyo's wards.  The AI also detects areas densely populated with wooden houses, allowing authorities to prioritize high-risk zones. This technological advancement underscores Tokyo's commitment to mitigating potential devastation from a major earthquake.

title: Trump falsely claims Harris crowd was faked
sum:
Donald Trump falsely claimed that a crowd gathered to see Vice President Kamala Harris speak in Michigan last week "didn't exist" and that an image showing it was AI-generated.  

Multiple images and videos from various sources, including news agencies, TV news teams, and attendees, show a large crowd present at the Democratic presidential nominee's rally in Detroit. Local media estimated around 15,000 people attended the event held at Detroit Metropolitan Airport. The Harris campaign confirmed that the photo in question was taken by their staff on an iPhone 12 Pro Max device on August 7th and has not been modified using AI.  

Trump's claim stemmed from a photo posted on X by a Harris campaign staffer, which showed a large crowd gathered behind the stage where Harris spoke. Some online users suggested elements of the photo were manipulated using AI, such as the absence of a reflection in a plane's side and the lack of an identification number on the tail. However, other photographs taken at the event show similar reflections and the missing identification number is also visible in footage from other events featuring Air Force Two. Prof Hany Farid, an image analysis specialist, analyzed the photo using software designed to detect AI-generated images and found no evidence of manipulation.
